{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} '''Color symbolism''' in [[art]] and [[anthropology]] refers to the use of color as a [[symbol]] in various [[Culture|cultures]]. There is great diversity in the use of colors and their associations between cultures<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Smith|first=N.S. |last2=Whitfield|first2=T.W.A. |last3=Wiltshire|first3=T.J. |date=April 1990 |title=The accuracy of the NCS, DIN, and OSA-UCS colour atlases |journal=Color Research & Application |volume=15 |issue=2 |pages=111–116 |doi=10.1002/col.5080150209 |issn=0361-2317}}</ref> and even within the same culture in different time periods.<ref>{{Cite book |title=Color psychology and color therapy: a factual study of the influence of color on human life |last=Birren |first=Faber |date=2006 |publisher=Kessinger Publishing |isbn=978-1425424107 |location=Whitefish, MT |oclc=74452551}}</ref> The same color may have very different associations within the same culture at any time. Diversity in color symbolism occurs because color meanings and symbolism occur on an individual, cultural and universal basis. Color symbolism is also context-dependent and influenced by changes over time.<ref>{{cite book |chapter=Color symbolism |doi=10.5040/9781501303364.ch-014 |title=Color Studies |editor1=Edith Anderson Feisner |editor2=Ronald Reed |edition=3rd |year=2016 |publisher=Bloomsbury |location=New York |isbn=978-1-50130-336-4 |oclc=1053938255 }}</ref> Symbolic representations of religious concepts or articles may include a specific color with which the concept or object is associated.<ref>{{Cite journal |language=de |title=Encyclopaedia Britannica|doi=10.1163/9789004337862_lgbo_com_050367 }}</ref> There is evidence to suggest that colors have been used for this purpose as early as 90,000 BC.{{fact|date=November 2018}}
== Common associations ==
=== Red === Red is often associated with love, passion, and lust. It is frequently used in relation to Valentine's Day.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.google.com/search?q=valentine&safe=off&source=lnms&tbm=isch&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiJobTilr7eAhWCLn0KHaP-BZIQ_AUIFCgC&biw=1366&bih=618 |title=valentine - Google Search|website=www.google.com|language=en|access-date=2018-11-05}}</ref> It can also be used to signify danger or warning. For instance, it is used for stop signs<ref>{{Citation|title=Road vertical signs. Variable message traffic signs|publisher=BSI British Standards|doi=10.3403/03263875u}}</ref> and fire engines.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.rocklandfirefighters.org/?zone=/unionactive/view_article.cfm&HomeID=50076&page=Fire20Department20Traditions|title=Why are fire trucks red?|website=www.rocklandfirefighters.org|access-date=2018-11-05}}</ref> In China, red is often used to symbolize good luck or happiness, and is used for many holidays or weddings.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.color-meanings.com/color-symbolism-in-chinese-culture-what-do-traditional-chinese-colors-mean/|title=Color Symbolism in Chinese Culture: What do Traditional Chinese Colors Mean?|date=2015-01-16|work=Color-Meanings.com|access-date=2018-11-06|language=en-US}}</ref>
=== Blue === Blue is the color of the ocean and the sky; it often symbolizes serenity, stability, or inspiration.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bourncreative.com/meaning-of-the-color-blue/|title=Meaning of The Color Blue {{!}}|last=|first=|date=2011-01-15|work=Bourn Creative|access-date=2018-11-05|language=en-US}}</ref> It can be a calming color, and symbolize reliability.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.color-meanings.com/blue-color-meaning-the-color-blue/|title=Blue Color Meaning - The Color Blue|last=|first=|date=2013-03-01|work=Color-Meanings.com|access-date=2018-11-05|language=en-US}}</ref> In the Catholic Church, the Virgin Mary is most often depicted wearing blue, to symbolize her divinity.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://aleteia.org/2017/06/24/why-is-the-blessed-virgin-mary-always-wearing-blue/|title=Why is the Blessed Virgin Mary always wearing blue?|last=|first=|date=2017-06-24|work=Aleteia — Catholic Spirituality, Lifestyle, World News, and Culture|access-date=2018-11-05|language=en-US}}</ref> Blue is widely used for baby boys' clothes or bedrooms, although the reason blue is so strongly associated with boys is debated.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.livescience.com/22037-pink-girls-blue-boys.html|title=Why Is Pink for Girls and Blue for Boys?|date=1 August 2012|first=Natalie|last=Wolchover|work=Live Science|access-date=7 November 2018}}</ref>
=== Yellow === Yellow is a color often associated with sunshine or joy.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.colormatters.com/the-meanings-of-colors/yellow|title=Yellow|last=Morton|first=Jill|website=www.colormatters.com|language=en-gb|access-date=2018-11-05}}</ref> It is sometimes used in association with cowardice or fear, i.e, the phrase "yellow-bellied".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.vocabulary.com/dictionary/yellow-bellied|title=yellow-bellied - Dictionary Definition|work=Vocabulary.com|access-date=2018-11-05}}</ref> Children tend to like this color, and it is used to market products to children;<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.bourncreative.com/meaning-of-the-color-yellow/|title=Meaning of The Color Yellow {{!}}|date=2011-02-05|work=Bourn Creative|access-date=2018-11-05|language=en-US}}</ref> it is also used for school buses and taxi cabs since it is such a bright, noticeable color.<ref name=":0" />
=== Green === Green is most often used to represent nature, healing, or fertility, since it's such a dominant color in nature. It can be a very relaxing color<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://www.bourncreative.com/meaning-of-the-color-green/|title=Meaning of The Color Green {{!}}|date=2011-01-25|work=Bourn Creative|access-date=2018-11-05|language=en-US}}</ref> but is also used in the US to symbolize money, greed, or jealousy.<ref name=":1" /> Saying that someone is "green" means they're inexperienced or new.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.collinsdictionary.com/us/dictionary/english/green|title=Green definition and meaning {{!}} Collins English Dictionary|website=www.collinsdictionary.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-11-05}}</ref>
=== Black === Black, in Western culture, is considered a negative color and usually symbolizes death, grief, or evil.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.colorpsychology.org/black/|title=Black Color Psychology - Black Meaning & Personality|work=Color Psychology|access-date=2018-11-05|language=en-US}}</ref> People often wear black for mourning, although this practice isn't as wide-spread as it was in the past.<ref>{{Citation|last=Jalland|first=Pat|date=1996-11-07|pages=77–97|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9780198201885|doi=10.1093/acprof:oso/9780198201885.003.0005|title=Death in the Victorian Family|chapter=Death and the Victorian Doctors}}</ref>
=== White === White most often symbolizes perfection, faith, innocence, softness, and cleanliness.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bourncreative.com/meaning-of-the-color-white/|title=Meaning of The Color White {{!}}|date=2010-12-05|work=Bourn Creative|access-date=2018-11-06|language=en-US}}</ref> Brides often wear white dresses to symbolize virginity or purity.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bridesmagazine.co.uk/article/why-do-brides-wear-white|title=Why Do Brides Wear White? And Other Questions|last=Davis|first=Lexxi|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref>
=== Pink === Pink is associated with softness, femininity, sweetness, and love.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bourncreative.com/meaning-of-the-color-pink/|title=Meaning of The Color Pink {{!}}|date=2010-11-15|work=Bourn Creative|access-date=2018-11-06|language=en-US}}</ref> However, it was formerly used as a masculine color, frequently used for baby boys; it wasn't until the early 20th century that the gender roles of pink and blue were reversed.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/01/12/health/colorscope-pink-boy-girl-gender/index.html|title=The complicated gender history of pink|last=Ant|first=Puja Bhattacharjee, CNN Animation by Giant|work=CNN|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref>
==Color symbolism in marketing== Color plays an important role in setting expectations for a product and communicating its key characteristics.<ref name=Asiam>{{Cite journal |last=Aslam |first=Mubeen M. |date=2006 |title=Are You Selling the Right Colour? A Cross‐Cultural Review of Colour as a Marketing Cue |journal=Journal of Marketing Communications |volume=12 |issue=1 |pages=15–30 |doi=10.1080/13527260500247827}}</ref> Color is the second most important element that allows consumers to identify brand packaging.<ref name=Popa>{{Cite journal|last=Popa|first=C.N. |last2=Popescu|first2=S. |last3=Berehoiu|first3=R.M.T. |last4=Berehoiu|first4=S.M.T. |date=2013 |title=Considerations regarding use and role of colour in marketing |url=http://managementjournal.usamv.ro/pdf/vol.XIII/Art44.pdf |journal= Scientific Papers Series - Management, Economic Engineering in Agriculture and Rural Development |volume=13 |issue=1 |pages=269–274}}</ref>
Marketers for products with an international market navigate the color symbolism variances between cultures with targeted advertising. The car manufacturer, Volkswagen ran a commercial in Italy with a black sheep in the middle of a larger flock symbolizing those who owned a VW Golf as someone unique and self-assured among a crowd of others who were not. In several cultures around the world, a black sheep represents an outcast and is seen as something undesirable. In Italy, a black sheep represents confidence and independence.[[File:Friaul Val Aupa Drentus Sheep credit Kaspar Nickles 2017.jpg|thumb|Friaul Val Aupa Drentus Sheep credit Kaspar Nickles 2017]] There are many additional variances in color symbolism between cultures. Cold is symbolized by blue in East Asia, the USA, and Sweden while warmth is symbolized by yellow in the USA and by blue in The Netherlands. Sometimes the meanings of colors are in stark opposition across geographic boundaries, requiring products marketed to specific demographics to account for those changes across different markets. For instance, feminity is symbolized by blue in The Netherlands and pink in the USA., whereas masculinity is symbolized by blue in Sweden and the USA, and red in the UK and France.<ref name=Asiam/> In some instances color symbolism in marketing is constructed. For companies whose products are defined by the name of their color their sales are susceptible to the symbolism and association of that name. In one example, a company selling a paint color named “off white” more than doubled its sales by renaming the same color as “ancient silk.”<ref name=Popa/>
==Conceptualizations of colors cross-culturally== Color symbolism has morphed over time. Between the 5th and 17th centuries color was largely related to in a religious context. Blue was symbolic of heaven and white of purity. Today, purity is still symbolized by white in Australia and the USA but by blue in other countries like India. Similarly, the church influenced the perception of colors like crimson and purple. Largely because the dyes for these colors could only be sourced from precious pigments, religious figures like Madonna, Cardinals, and the Virgin were seen in scarlet and purple. [[File:Vatican II - Dubois - Liénart.JPG|thumb|Vatican II - Dubois - Liénart]]Today, purple symbolizes evil and infidelity in Japan, but the same is symbolized by blue in East Asia and by yellow in France. Additionally, the sacred color of Hindu and Buddhist monks is orange. [[File:Preah Pithu T Monks - Siem Reap.jpg|thumb|Preah Pithu T Monks - Siem Reap]] The Renaissance was also a time in which black and purple were colors of mourning. Today, Mourning or death is symbolized by white in East Asia, black in the USA, and blue in Iran, while happiness is symbolized by white in Australia and NZ, and yellow in China.<ref name=Asiam/>
There is a general disagreement over whether reactions to color and their symbolism are a result of cultural conditioning or of instinct. Several studies concluded that color is part of the social learning process because of the significant symbolism within the culture. High quality, trustworthiness and dependability are symbolized by blue in the USA, Japan, Korea and green and yellow in China - as well as purple in China, South Korea and Japan. Because of these variances, critical cues vary across cultures. Warning signs are coded differently as danger is symbolized by green in Malaysia, and red in the USA and Mexico. The same color of green symbolizes envy in Belgium and the USA, but envy is symbolized by yellow in Germany and Russia, and purple in Mexico. Even the colors that denote powerful emotions vary. Love is symbolized by green in Japan, red and purple in China, Korea, Japan and the USA. Unluckiness is symbolized by red in Chad, Nigeria and Germany. Luckiness is symbolized by red in China, Denmark and Argentina. The traditional bridal color is red in China and white in the USA. Ambition and desire are symbolized by red in India.<ref name=Asiam/>
== Color symbolism in Arabic culture == Color has different meanings in different countries. We can specifically look at the Arabic culture and take it into consideration. We can start with the color white. In the Arabic culture, white is thought of as the color that is symbolic for nature. Since it related with nature, it has a meaning that is one of positivity. It also relates with that of being clean and pure. White is a color that is commonly worn during prayers and with that, it symbolizes purity. White’s positive connotation carries out into other aspects. It is also used as a symbol for positivity in the future. White is also used to symbolize the end of war. You will also see women adorn white at their weddings as a sign of positivity. Since doves are white, they share the symbolic meaning that comes with the color. This in turn causes them to be associated with positivity of good news.
When you look at the color Black in Arabic culture you can find that it is related to funerals and death. Women will often wear black to funerals in order to show that they are sad for those who have passed. Also relating to death, black is associated with hell. Black is also used to symbolize dark. Hell is thought to be a dark black place associating black as negative. Black in general is looked at as having negative connotations around it. For example, the symbolism of a black heart refers to someone who is unkind. [[File:Red rose with black background.jpg|thumb]] Green is a color that is commonly found in Islam. It is a color found in nature and with this, it is associated with and represents goodness. Green is a color that has an overall positive meaning. The color green also has to do with truthfulness, again going with positivity. If you look at phrases, the symbolic meanings are generally positive. If you look at the phrase green hand, it relates to being generous which is a positive thing.
Red has an overall positive association with it. Often you will find that red is a color associated with roses and blood. The color red has to do with love and passion. In sayings you can find it to have either a negative or positive meaning such as the term red eye relates with anger. The Arabic culture also associates this color with death.
Blue is related with positivity when discussing it with nature, otherwise it can be related with negative connotations. When used in the phrase blue eyes, it refers to jealousy. A blue body relates with death and therefore is associated with negativity.
Yellow is another color that is also associated with nature and the sun. Again, since it is a color related with nature, it takes on the symbolic meaning of positivity. Gold is also categorized under here and is also takes on a positive meaning. Generally, when used in phrases, the color yellow has to do with negativity. For example, a yellow smile means to be mean.
<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hasan|first=Amna|date=2011|title=How Colours are Semantically Construed in the Arabic and English Culture: A Comparative study|url=https://files.eric.ed.gov/fulltext/EJ1080712.pdf|journal=English Language Teaching|volume=4|pages=206–213|via=}}</ref> ==Colors and emotions== [[File:Emotions - 3.png|thumb]] Color symbolism is displayed in many ways. One of the most common ways we see color symbolism displayed in through our emotions. In this article Color-emotions associations: Past experience and personal preference it takes a look at how we connect colors with our emotions and how it depends on a person’s preference and or their past experiences. This article first starts out by talking about the different colors and what they are associated with. The first color it talks about is the color blue and how people see blue as comfort and security and how they see orange as being upsetting. The next one they talk about is yellow which is more of a happy color compared to purple which they say is dignified but I have never heard of purple being seen that way. The next one this article talks about which I find very interesting is the color red. People view the color red in two different ways, one being as a strong and passionate color. However, it is also seen in a very different way, people see it as an aggressive color because it is the color of blood. The last color this article talks about is the color green and how just like red it has two different views. Green can be viewed positively as in quietness but can also be viewed negatively as in guilt. This study took a look at how we associate colors with emotions. This study was done and showed that we associated lighter colors such as blue or yellow with more positive emotions. It then showed how we associated darker colors such as grey or black with more native emotions. However, something very interesting that this study did find is that most young prefer the color black over many other colors. The study was done with college aged students to see how they associate their emotions with colors. Many tests were done such as matching tasks and matching color tests to see what colors they associate with their emotions. The study had 44 men and 54 women in it and they again were all college students. They identified a color sample with one emotion only and it showed what emotional response is connected to a color. The results from this study did find that people mostly associate the color green with being the most positive. Over 95% off people said that green s the most positive because it makes them feel relaxed and then comfortable and at peace. It also showed that people saw yellow as the more excited and energetic emotion, with over 90% agreeing with this. 79% of students found that blue was a calming color because it reminded them of the ocean which is known as a calming place. People did have different answers when it came to red because like explained earlier, red is seen in two very different ways, It has been seen as love by many but also as evil because it remind people of blood. Many people did not seem to like the color purple very much as it was not favored by many for their preferences. The color black was seen to be more negative emotions like fear and depression. Overall, this article shows how color can be important because it is how people associate their emotions and things based on color symbolism.<ref>Kaya & H., Naz & Helen. Color-emotion association: Past experience and personal preference. The University of Georgia, Department of Textiles, Merchandising, and Interiors, 2004.</ref> <ref>{{Cite web | url=https://books.google.com/?id=lCoAb9RDVIYC&pg=PA31&dq=color+symbolism+#v=onepage&q=color%20symbolism&f=false | title=AIC 2004 Color and Paints, Interim Meeting of the International Color Association, Proceedings}}</ref>

[[File:This Is the House That Jack Built.jpg|thumb|Cumulative tale [[This Is the House That Jack Built]]]]
In a '''cumulative tale''', sometimes also called a '''chain tale''', action or dialogue repeats and builds up in some way as the tale progresses. With only the sparest of plots, these tales often depend upon repetition and rhythm for their effect, and can require a skilled storyteller to negotiate their tongue-twisting repetitions in performance.<ref name=greenwood>{{cite encyclopedia |last= Ashliman|first= D.L.|authorlink=D. L. Ashliman|editor= Donald. Haase|encyclopedia= The Greenwood encyclopedia of folktales and fairy tales |title=Chain Tale|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=w9KEk9wQPjkC|publisher= Greenwood Press|isbn= 978-0-313-33441-2|page= 176}}</ref> The climax is sometimes abrupt and sobering as in "[[The Gingerbread Man]]." The device often takes the form of a [[cumulative song]] or [[nursery rhyme]]. Many cumulative tales feature a series of animals or forces of nature each more powerful than the last.
==History== Cumulative tales have a long pedigree. In an early Jewish [[Midrash]], considered to date from the sixth century AD, [[Abraham]] is brought before King [[Nimrod]], who commands him to worship fire.<ref>See the [[Nimrod#Text of the Midrash Raba version|Text of the Midrash Raba version]]. This is not itself a cumulative tale, though many cumulative tales seem to echo its theme.</ref> Abraham replies that it would be more reasonable to worship water, which can quench fire and is therefore more powerful. When this premise is granted, he points out that the clouds, as sustainers of water, are more worthy of worship, and then that the wind that disperses them is more powerful still. Finally he confronts Nimrod with the observation that "man can stand up against the wind or shield himself behind the walls of his house" ([[Genesis Rabba]] xxxviii).
There is a similar tale, [[The Mouse Turned into a Maid]], in the [[Panchatantra]], in which the mouse-maid is successively introduced to the sun, the cloud, the wind and the mountain. She prefers each in turn as stronger than the last, but finally a mouse is found to be stronger than even the mountain, and so she marries the mouse. Stories of this type, such as the Japanese [[The Husband of the Rat's Daughter]], are widely diffused.<ref>[[D. L. Ashliman]], "[http://www.pitt.edu/~dash/type2031c.html The Mouse Who Was to Marry the Sun: fables of Aarne-Thompson type 2031C]"</ref>
==Classification== In the [[Aarne-Thompson]] classification system, types 2000-2100 are all cumulative tales, including:<ref>[http://www.pitt.edu/~dash/folktexts.html D. L. Ashliman's page of story types]</ref> *'''Chains Based on Numbers, Objects, Animals, or Names 2000-2020''' *:How the rich man paid his servant 2010 *:The house is burned down 2014 *:The goat that would not go home 2015 *:[[Fair Katrinelje and Pif-Paf-Poltrie]] 2019 *'''Chains Involving Death 2021-2024''' *:The cock and the hen 2021 *:[[The Louse and the Flea|An Animal Mourns the Death of a Spouse]] 2022 *'''Chains Involving Eating 2025-2028''' *: [[The Gingerbread Man|The Fleeing Pancake]] 2025 *: The fat cat 2027 *'''Chains Involving Other Events 2029-2075''' *: The Old Woman and Her Pig 2030<ref>[http://www.authorama.com/english-fairy-tales-6.html The Old Woman and Her Pig], ''English Fairy Tales'' by [[Joseph Jacobs]], Everyman's Library 1993 {{ISBN|978-1-85715-917-2}} [http://www.authorama.com/english-fairy-tales-47.html In his notes] Jacobs gives the source of this tale as ''Halliwell’s Nursery Rhymes and Tales, 114'', lists parallels and mentions that it is one "of the class of Accumulative stories, which are well represented in England."</ref> *: [[The Sky Is Falling (fable)|The Sky Is Falling]] 2033 *: [[This Is the House That Jack Built]] 2035 *: The Mouse Who Was to Marry the Sun 2031C ([[The Husband of the Rat's Daughter|Japanese]], [[The Mouse Turned into a Maid|Indian]]) *: Pulling up the turnip 2044 *: Tales in which animals talk 2075
==Other examples of cumulative tales== * "The Death of the Little Hen"<ref>The first part of this tale is cumulative. Collected by the Brothers Grimm; given in [[s:The Death of the Little Hen|Wikisource]].</ref> * [[Why Mosquitoes Buzz in People's Ears]] * [[The Fisherman and His Wife]] * [[The Stonecutter]] * [[Chad Gadya]] * [[Green Eggs and Ham]] * [[Drummer Hoff]] * [[There Was an Old Lady Who Swallowed a Fly]] * I Bought Me a Cat, featured in the 1950 [[Aaron Copland]] song set [[Old American Songs]] * [http://www.pitt.edu/~dash/type2030.html The Old Woman and the Pig] * The Train to Glasgow by Wilma Horsbrugh [http://skinnyfairtradelatte.blogspirit.com/archive/2010/07/19/the-train-to-glasgow.html], later set to music by [[The Singing Kettle]] * [[And The Green Grass Grew All Around]] * [[Old MacDonald Had a Farm]] * A Fly Went By * Court of King Caractacus - song by [[Rolf Harris]], later recorded by The Singing Kettle * [[The Twelve Days of Christmas (song)|The Twelve Days of Christmas]] * [[Green Grow the Rushes, O]] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5YvAz8g9Aqs No News, or What Killed the Dog?] by [[Nat M. Wills]]

'''Dancing England''' was a series of showcase traditional dance concerts held at the Derby Assembly Rooms from 1979 to 1987. They were devised and curated by Phil Heaton and John Shaw, members of the Black Cap Sword Dancers, and two very notable characters on the Nottingham and Derby folk and dance scene of the 1970s. Dancing England was set up to showcase the best of traditional dance in the UK, along with unique and/or interesting folk customs to celebrate the UK's wide cultural heritage.
==Dancing England gone by==
In 1979 Phil and John of Black Cap decided to hold a 'Feast' and invite the best dancers from across the UK as their guests, and so the idea of Dancing England was born.<ref>[http://www.the-nut.net/articles/phil.php] The Nut on the Web. Retrieved on 2016-04-07.</ref>
The event was held in the evening and consisted of a series of performances by dance teams across all the styles of UK traditional dance; [[Morris dance|Cotswold Morris]], [[Rapper sword]], [[Long Sword dance|Longsword]], North West, [[Clog dance (British)|step clog dancing]], [[Border Morris|Border]], [[Molly dance|Molly]], and much more. There were also performances by [[Mummers play|mummers]] and [[Pace Egg play|Pace Eggers]], musicians and from some of the more idiosyncratic traditional teams; notably [[Britannia Coco-nut Dancers|The Britannia Coconut Dancers]], [[Abbots Bromley Horn Dance|Abbotts Bromley Horn Dancers]] and the [[Whittlesey#Whittlesea Straw Bear|Whittlesey Straw Bear]]. There were stalls selling music, ephemera and crafts, films, workshops and talks. The event was refreshed with plenty of real ale, and finished with a ceilidh late at night.
==Notable teams from 1979 to 1987==
*1979 - Abbotts Bromley Horn Dancers, Britannia Coconut Dancers, Handsworth Longsword, Monkseaton Morrismen (Rapper), Minehead Hobby 'Oss, Shropshire Bedlams, Bampton Cotswold Morris Men, Manley Morris Dancers, Winster Morris, Peter Brown (Step Dancing) *1980 - Abbotts Bromley Horn Dancers, Britannia Coconut Dancers, Mepal Molly Dancers, Grenoside Longsword, Colne Royal Morris, Silurian Border Morris, Winster Morris, Chipping Camden Morris, Old Ball, Royal Earsdon Sword, Doris Hawkes (Clog dancing) Ram's Bottom Blood Tubs, Tony Mannion(hornpipe & step dance) *1981 - The Artichoke Pipe Dance, Kingsmen Rapper Sword, Horwich Prize Medal Morris, Cambridge Molly Men, Redcar Longsword, Jane Flett & Lindsay Smith, Winster Morris, Abingdon Morris, Haxey Hood, Jane Flett& Lindsay Smith (stepdance), Cyril Papworth (Broomdance), Monkseaton Country Dancers, Monkseaton Egg Dancers, Cambridge Molly Men, Silurian Border Morris, *1982 - Whittlesey Straw Bear, The Iron Men, Loftus Longsword, Fidler's Fancy Morris, Headington Quarry Morris, High Spen Rapper, Harper's Frolick Dancers, Winster Morris, Antrobus Soulcakers, Leyland N.W. Morris, Grovely Faggot, Lichfield Greenhill Bower & Green Man's Morris, Monkseaton Morrismen (Rapper) *1983 - Bampton Morris Men, Bob Cann and Sally Hooper - Devon Step Dancers, Brant Broughton Lincolnshire Plough Boys, Cam Kernewek Cornish Dancers, Flamborough Longsword Dancers, Fred Forster's High Spen Rapper, Grovelly Faggott Dancers of Wiltshire, Lymm and Statham Morris, Poynton Jemmers Cheshire Morris, Shropshire Bedlams Welsh Border Morris, Snap the Dragon from Norwich, Tideswell Town Band Processional Morris, Winster Derbyshire Morris and Woodfidley Playford Dancers *1984 - Eynsham Morris, Wooden Horse from Kent, East Yorkshire Vessel Cuppers, Midgeley Pace Eggers, Pat Tracey, Rochester Dancing Sweeps, Royal Earsdon Rapper *1985 - The Salisbury Giant, Lichfield Morris, Goathland Plough Stots, East Sussex Frailers, Breinton Border Morris, Nottingham Butchers, The Throstles Nest *1986 - Aidleys Morris, Bampton Morris Men, Bob Cann & Sally Hooper, Cam Kernewek Cornish Dancers, Flamborough Longsword Dancers, Poynton Jemmers, Grovelly Faggot Dancers *1987 - Abbotts Bromley Horn Dancers, Fidler's Fancy, Pyewackett, Straw Bear, Hugh Rippon, Iron Men and Severn Guilders, Gorton Morris, Grenoside Longsword, Chipping Camden Morris, Mepal Molly Men, Winster Morris, The Old Hat Band, Peter Brown, Bryan Jackson, The Flett Sisters and East Anglian Step Dancers
==Daughter of Dancing England==
After Dancing England came to an end in 1987, there was a brief reprise in 1993 at the same venue for the Daughter of Dancing England event. This only ran for one year, and both Dancing England and Daughter of same were sadly missed.
==The Dancing England Rapper Tournament (DERT)==
Dancing England featured a rapper sword competition in the afternoon prior to the evening concert, in homage to the Newcastle Tournament of Music and Art which was held in the city from just after the Great War until the 1950s. Following the sad demise of Dancing England in 1987, the competition continued under the name of [[Dancing England Rapper Tournament|DERT]] and now travels around the country being hosted by a different rapper sword team every year.
==The modern Dancing England Series, 2017 onwards==
2019 - Nottingham Playhouse; Saturday 26th January 2019
2017 - Sheffield City Hall; Saturday 18 February 2017.

<!-- Area --> |unit_pref = Imperial |area_footnotes = |area_total_sq_mi =0.050 |population_as_of = [[United States Census, 2010|2010]] |population_footnotes = |population_total = 1,139 |population_note = |population_density_km2 = auto
<!-- Area/postal codes & others --> |postal_code_type = [[Zip code|ZIP Codes]] |postal_code = 11201 |area_code = [[Area codes 718, 347, and 929|718, 347, 929]], and [[Area code 917|917]] |blank_name = [[Household income in the United States|Median household income]] |blank_info = $171,842<ref name="Detailed Profile">{{cite web |title=Dumbo neighborhood in Brooklyn, New York (NY), 11201 detailed profile |url=http://www.city-data.com/neighborhood/Dumbo-Brooklyn-NY.html |work=City-Data.com |publisher=Urban Mapping, Inc. |accessdate=September 6, 2015}}</ref> |website = |footnotes = {{Infobox NRHP | name = DUMBO Industrial District | embed = yes | nrhp_type = hd | nocat = yes | image = Plymouthst.JPG | caption = Plymouth Street, DUMBO Industrial District, March 2008 | location= Roughly bounded by Main and Washington Sts, East River, John St., Bridge and Jay Sts., and Front and York Sts., [[Brooklyn, New York]] | coordinates = {{coord|40|42|11|N|73|59|17|W|region:US-NY_type:landmark|display=inline}} | locmapin = New York City#New York#USA | built = 1883 | architect = multiple | architecture = Greek Revival, Italianate, et al. | added = September 22, 2000 | area = {{convert|48|acre}} | governing_body = Local | refnum = 00001151<ref name="nris">{{NRISref|version=2009a}}</ref> }} }}
'''Dumbo''' (or '''DUMBO''',<ref name="dolkart"/><ref name="nyt2007-12-25">{{cite news |title=Dumbo Journal: District Trying to Forge a New Identity |first=Anne |last=Barnard |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/12/25/nyregion/25journal.html |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=December 25, 2007 |accessdate=September 6, 2015}}</ref> short for '''D'''own '''U'''nder the '''M'''anhattan '''B'''ridge '''O'''verpass) is a neighborhood in the [[New York City]] [[borough (New York City)|borough]] of [[Brooklyn]]. The area known as DUMBO used to be known as Gairville.<ref>{{cite news | first= David W. |last= Dunlap| title= SoHo, TriBeCa And Now Dumbo? |url = https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/25/realestate/soho-tribeca-and-now-dumbo.html |work= New York Times |date=October 25, 1998 | accessdate=April 19, 2017}}</ref> It encompasses two sections: one located between the [[Manhattan Bridge|Manhattan]] and [[Brooklyn Bridge]]s, which connect Brooklyn to [[Manhattan]] across the [[East River]], and another that continues east from the Manhattan Bridge to the [[Vinegar Hill, Brooklyn|Vinegar Hill]] area. The neighborhood is bounded by [[Brooklyn Bridge Park]] to the north, the [[Brooklyn Bridge]] to the west, [[Brooklyn Heights]] to the south and Vinegar Hill to the east. Dumbo is part of [[Brooklyn Community Board 2]].
The area was originally a [[ferry]] landing, characterized by 19th- and early 20th-century industrial and warehouse buildings, [[Sett (paving)|Belgian block]] streets, and its location on the East River by the imposing anchorage of the Manhattan Bridge. The entirety of Dumbo was bought by developer [[David Walentas]] and his company Two Trees Management in the late 20th century, and remade into an upscale residential and commercial community—first becoming a haven for art [[Art museum|galleries]], and currently a center for technology [[Startup company|startups]].
The large community of tech startups earned DUMBO the nickname of "the center of the Brooklyn Tech Triangle". In that time, Dumbo had become Brooklyn's most expensive neighborhood, as well as New York City's fourth-richest community overall; this is owing in part to its large concentration of technology [[Startup company|startups]], its close proximity to Manhattan, and its large number of former industrial buildings that have been converted into spacious [[luxury real estate|luxury]] residential [[lofts]].<ref>{{cite web | last=Nonko | first=Emily | title=The 8 Most Expensive Neighborhoods in New York City | website=New York.com | date=January 27, 2015 | url=http://www.newyork.com/articles/real-estate/the-most-expensive-neighborhoods-in-new-york-city-75971 | accessdate=November 7, 2015 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151029075613/http://www.newyork.com/articles/real-estate/the-most-expensive-neighborhoods-in-new-york-city-75971/ | archivedate=October 29, 2015 | df= }}</ref> The neighborhood is the corporate headquarters for e-commerce retailer [[Etsy]] and home furnishing stores company [[West Elm]].
==Name== {{stack|float=left| [[File:Street fair under the Manhattan Bridge overpass, July 2017.jpg|thumb|upright=1.3|A [[street fair]] under the Manhattan Bridge overpass in July 2017|left]] [[File:Empire State framed by Manhattan Bridge July 2017.jpg|upright=1.3|left|thumb|The [[Manhattan Bridge]], framing the [[Empire State Building]] beneath, as seen from Washington Street]]}} The name is an [[acronym]] of "Down Under the Manhattan Bridge Overpass". Several other New York City neighborhoods are known by [[portmanteau]]s, including [[Tribeca]], [[SoHo, Manhattan|SoHo]], [[NoHo, Manhattan|NoHo]], [[NoMad]], and [[Nolita]] in Manhattan, and [[BoCoCa]] in Brooklyn.<ref name="dolkart">{{Cite book |last1=Dolkart |first1=Andrew S. |url=http://home2.nyc.gov/html/lpc/downloads/pdf/reports/DUMBO_Designation_Report.pdf |title=DUMBO Historic District Designation Report |publisher=[[New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission]] |date=December 18, 2007 |accessdate=September 6, 2015|display-authors=etal}}</ref><ref name="nyt2007-12-25"/>
==History== The area has been known variously as Rapailie, Olympia, and Walentasville.<ref name="DumboNYC">{{cite web |title=About Dumbo |url=http://dumbonyc.com/about |work=Dumbo NYC, Brooklyn |publisher=DumboNYC.com |accessdate=December 10, 2012}}</ref> The "Olympia" name came from [[Comfort Sands|Comfort]] and [[Joshua Sands (politician)|Joshua Sands]], who bought the land in 1787<ref>{{Cite book|title = The Olympia Settlement in Early Brooklyn|last = |first = |publisher = |year = 1929|isbn = |location = New York|pages = }}</ref> and were planning to develop the land as a summer place for New Yorkers.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Dictionary of American Biography|last = Johnson|first = Allen|publisher = Charles Scribner’s Sons|year = 1964|isbn = |location = New York|pages = 341–342}}</ref> Through the 18th and 19th centuries, the area now known as Dumbo was considered part of [[Vinegar Hill, Brooklyn|Vinegar Hill]].<ref name="HISTORICAL DISTRICTS 1966">{{Cite journal|date=1966|title=HISTORICAL DISTRICTS|url=http://www.jstor.org/stable/20780654|journal=Real Property, Probate and Trust Journal|volume=1|issue=3|pages=204–211}}</ref>
In the 1890s, the western portion of the neighborhood was known as [[Fulton Landing]], after the [[ferry]] stop that connected it to Manhattan before the [[Brooklyn Bridge]] opened. At that time, it was primarily a manufacturing district, with warehouses and factories that made machinery, paper boxes and [[Brillo]] soap pads. The area has been known variously as Rapailie, Olympia, and Walentasville.<ref name="DumboNYC"/> The [[cardboard box]] was invented in the Robert Gair building on Washington Street by Robert Gair, a Scottish emigrant; because of Gair's fame, the area was known as Gairsville for a long time.<ref name="DumboNYC"/> The Gair building is now home to [[Etsy]].<ref name="usa"/>>
The [[Jay Street Connecting Railroad]] ran through Dumbo's waterfront from circa 1904–1906 through 1957. It ran from rail yards beneath the Manhattan and Brooklyn Bridges to buildings near the waterfront in Dumbo and Vinegar Hill. At the height of operations, it had spurs into several buildings, a [[car float bridge]] on Bridge Street, and a yard with capacity of 120 cars.<ref>{{cite web | title=Jay Street Terminal / Jay Street Connecting Railroad | website=TrainWeb.org | date=November 30, 2017 | url=http://members.trainweb.com/bedt/indloco/jst.html | access-date=November 28, 2018}}</ref><ref name=NYPress-JSC-2003>{{cite web|url=http://www.nypress.com/the-jay-street-connecting-railroad/|title=The Jay Street Connecting Railroad|first=William|last=Bryk|date=April 22, 2003|work=NY Press}}</ref> The tracks were abandoned in 1959,<ref>{{cite web | title=RAIL LINE TO END ITS BROOKLYN RUN; Jay Street Connecting Road Allowed to Discontinue Operations in Harbor | website=The New York Times | date=April 16, 1959 | url=https://www.nytimes.com/1959/04/16/archives/rail-line-to-end-its-brooklyn-run-jay-street-connecting-road.html | access-date=November 28, 2018}}</ref> though the railroad's tracks are still visible on streets in Dumbo.<ref name=NYPress-JSC-2003/>
With the [[deindustrialization]] of New York City, Dumbo began to become primarily residential; artists and other young homesteaders seeking relatively large and inexpensive [[loft apartment]] spaces for studios and homes began moving there in the late 1970s.<ref name="nyt2007-12-25"/> The acronym "Dumbo" arose in 1978, when new residents coined it in the belief such an unattractive name would help deter developers.<ref name="nyt2007-12-25"/>
Near the end of the 20th century, as property became more and more expensive in Manhattan, Dumbo became increasingly [[gentrification|gentrified]]. Even so, the acronym 'Dumbo' was largely unknown as late as 1997, and the area itself was very inclusive, serving mainly as an enclave for artists located along the [[East River]] and under the [[Manhattan Bridge]]. At this stage there were still many air conditioner repair shops, auto shops, and "seedy back alleys and wharves"; and, because the neighborhood was still gentrifying from its industrial past, it lacked even a bookstore, coffee shop, or [[Self-service laundry|laundromat]].<ref name="nyt 19971010">[https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9D0CE3DC153CF933A25753C1A961958260&pagewanted=all "As It Turns Artistic, A Noirish Enclave Steps Into the Light"]. October 10, 1997. ''New York Times'' article by Peter Marks; accessed November 12, 2010.</ref> The efforts of [[Joy Glidden]], the Founding Director of the Dumbo Arts Center (DAC) and co-founder of the Dumbo Art Under the Bridge Festival, achieved successful development in Dumbo, which is now a model for similar waterfront developments around the world.<ref>[http://soulofbrooklyn.com/neighborhoods/dumbo/ Dumbo - Soul of Brooklyn] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140214045443/http://soulofbrooklyn.com/neighborhoods/dumbo/ |date=February 14, 2014 }}. "The DUMBO Arts Center was founded by Joy Glidden and under her direction from 1997-2006 has helped to establish a successful model for waterfront development that has been referred to and used internationally". Retrieved June 12, 2014.</ref> Glidden stated of Dumbo's gentrification, "It may be one of the last of what could be considered a true arts community in New York."<ref name="nyt 19971010"/>
The DUMBO Historic District, a historic industrial complex and national [[Historic district (United States)|historic district]] in Dumbo, was listed on the [[National Register of Historic Places]] in 2000.<ref name="nris"/> It consists of 95 contributing buildings; the manufacturing concerns located in this district included [[Benjamin Moore & Co.]] (paint), Arbuckle Brothers (coffee and sugar), J.W. Masury & Son (paint), Robert Gair (paper boxes), E.W. Bliss (machinery), and Brillo (soap pads). The district includes the earliest large-scale [[reinforced concrete]] factory buildings in America.<ref name="nrhpinv_ny">{{cite web|url=http://www.oprhp.state.ny.us/hpimaging/hp_view.asp?GroupView=3049|title=National Register of Historic Places Registration:DUMBO Industrial District|date=June 2000|accessdate=March 6, 2011|author=Kathy Howe|publisher=[[New York State Office of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation]]|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121019090418/http://www.oprhp.state.ny.us/hpimaging/hp_view.asp?GroupView=3049|archivedate=October 19, 2012|df=}} ''See also:'' {{cite web|url=http://www.oprhp.state.ny.us/hpimaging/hp_view.asp?GroupView=3048|title=Accompanying 20 photos|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121019090434/http://www.oprhp.state.ny.us/hpimaging/hp_view.asp?GroupView=3048|archivedate=October 19, 2012|df=}}</ref> On December 18, 2007, the [[New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission]] voted unanimously to designate Dumbo as the city's 90th historic district. The Dumbo historic district consists of properties bound by John Street to the north, York Street to the south, Main Street to the west, and Bridge Street to the east.<ref>{{cite press release |publisher=[[New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission]] |date=December 18, 2007 |format=PDF |title=Landmarks Preservation Commission Designates Dumbo as New York City's 90th Historic District |url=http://www.nyc.gov/html/lpc/downloads/pdf/press/12_18_07.pdf |accessdate=July 3, 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121020232259/http://www.nyc.gov/html/lpc/downloads/pdf/press/12_18_07.pdf |archive-date=October 20, 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
==Land use== {{stack|float=right|[[File:Plymouthst.JPG|upright|thumb|right|Looking westward from Jay Street along Plymouth Street, through Dumbo, under the Manhattan Bridge, at a pier of the [[Brooklyn Bridge]]]]}}
===Art, business, and leisure=== The area has emerged as one of New York City's premier arts districts, with a cluster of for-profit art galleries such as the Klompching Gallery, and such not-for-profit institutions as the [[St. Ann's Warehouse]] and the [[A.I.R. Gallery]].
Chef [[Chocolate with Jacques Torres|Jacques Torres]] opened a chocolate factory in Dumbo in December 2000.<ref>{{cite news |title='Mr Chocolate' blazed a sweet trail for retailers - Jacques Torres Chocolates |first=Peter |last=Moore |url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m3601/is_27_50/ai_113898100 |newspaper=Real Estate Weekly |date=February 18, 2004 |accessdate=July 3, 2010}}</ref> Other culinary businesses in the area include [[Grimaldi's]],<ref>{{cite web |title=Pizza Madness: Grimaldi Taking Over Grimaldi's When Grimaldi Moves Next Door |first=Joanna |last=Shaw |url=http://nonabrooklyn.com/pizza-madness-grimaldi-taking-over-grimaldis-when-grimaldis-moves-next-door/ |work=Nona Brooklyn |date=November 29, 2011 |accessdate=November 29, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111209084545/http://nonabrooklyn.com/pizza-madness-grimaldi-taking-over-grimaldis-when-grimaldis-moves-next-door/ |archivedate=December 9, 2011 |df= }}</ref> the [[Brooklyn Ice Cream Factory]],<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/02/01/nyregion/neighborhood-report-fulton-ferry-some-landmarks-are-just-meant-to-be-a-problem.html |title=FULTON FERRY; Some Landmarks Are Just Meant to Be a Problem |publisher=The New York Times |date=February 1, 2004 |accessdate=April 29, 2011}}</ref> and The River Café,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://therivercafe.com|title=The River Café Restaurant - Brooklyn, New York - Established 1977|website=The River Café|accessdate=July 14, 2018}}</ref> all clustered in Fulton Landing, also home to [[Bargemusic]], a floating venue for classical music.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9D0CE3D9173BF933A1575BC0A967958260 |title=Music in Review |accessdate=August 4, 2008 |date=August 20, 1991 |author=Allan Kozinn |work=The New York Times}}</ref>
Invitations for the [[first inauguration of Barack Obama|2009 presidential inauguration]] of U.S. President [[Barack Obama]] were printed by Dumbo printer Precise Continental.<ref>{{cite news |title='Inside a Gritty Brooklyn Factory, Potomac Fever |first=Caroline |last=Dworin |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/12/21/nyregion/thecity/21prin.html |work=New York Times |date=December 19, 2008 |accessdate=January 31, 2016}}</ref>
The first public space in the neighborhood was [[Fulton Ferry, Brooklyn|Fulton Ferry]],<ref>{{cite web|title=New York Water Taxi Begins Service From Fulton Ferry |url=http://www.ny1.com/content/top_stories/64607/new-york-water-taxi-begins-service-from-fulton-ferry |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130630011834/http://www.ny1.com/content/top_stories/64607/new-york-water-taxi-begins-service-from-fulton-ferry |dead-url=yes |archive-date=June 30, 2013 |publisher=NY1 |accessdate=November 27, 2006 }}</ref> followed by [[Empire-Fulton Ferry State Park]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Empire Fulton Ferry |url=http://www.brooklynbridgepark.org/the-park/empire-fulton-ferry-open |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121014141311/http://www.brooklynbridgepark.org/the-park/empire-fulton-ferry-open |archivedate=October 14, 2012 |accessdate=September 6, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Calder |first=Rich |title=Brooklyn Bridge Park finally set to open |url=http://www.nypost.com/p/brooklyn_bridge_park_finally_set_bym9agsosKay1dnTONph0L |accessdate=October 24, 2013 |newspaper=New York Post |date=December 17, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100118182829/http://www.nypost.com/p/brooklyn_bridge_park_finally_set_bym9agsosKay1dnTONph0L |archivedate=January 18, 2010 }}</ref> The first six acres of [[Brooklyn Bridge Park]], a joint state/city venture under development, were opened in March 2010.<ref>{{cite press release|title=Governor Paterson and Mayor Bloomberg Open First Section of Brooklyn Bridge Park |publisher=New York State |url=http://www.governor.ny.gov/archive/paterson/press/032210BrooklynBridgePark.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20121214041818/http://www.governor.ny.gov/archive/paterson/press/032210BrooklynBridgePark.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=December 14, 2012 |date=March 22, 2010 |accessdate=April 4, 2012 }}</ref>
The building at 200 Water Street, which the Brillo Manufacturing Co. once occupied, is being renovated as a high-end condo building.<ref>{{Cite news |title=In Dumbo, a Study in Industrial Chic |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/in-dumbo-a-study-in-industrial-chic-1449708719 |newspaper=Wall Street Journal|access-date = December 11, 2015 |issn=0099-9660 |first=Josh |last=Barbanel}}</ref>
{{Clear left}}
===Tech hub=== {{see also|New York Digital District}} Dumbo has New York City's highest concentration of technology firms by neighborhood.<ref name="usa">Graham, Jefferson. (May 7, 2013). ''It's hip to be tech in Brooklyn's Dumbo''. USA TODAY, p 5B.</ref> Dumbo is home to 25 percent of New York City-based tech firms. Within a 10-block radius are 500 tech and creative firms that employ over 10,000 people.<ref name="usa"/> It also contains the corporate headquarters for e-commerce retailer [[Etsy]]<ref>[Goodman, Wendy. [http://nymag.com/thecut/2014/08/etsy-office-tour.html "See Inside Etsy’s Seriously Fun Brooklyn Office"], ''[[New York (magazine)]]'', August 14, 2014. Accessed September 27, 2016. "The other day, I took a tour of Etsy's Dumbo offices and was pleased to find them as original, wacky, and one-of-a-kind as a workplace can get."</ref> and home furnishing stores company [[West Elm]].<ref>Gurfein, Laura. [http://ny.racked.com/2015/1/13/7561379/west-elm-dumbo "Here's the First Look at West Elm's New Dumbo Home"], [[Racked.com]], January 13, 2015. Accessed September 27, 2016.</ref>
[[File:Pearl Street Pocket Park.jpg|thumb|left|upright=1.1|Pearl Street [[pocket park]] in Dumbo]] The City of New York, in conjunction with [[New York University]], installed an incubator in Dumbo to support development of tech start-ups.<ref name="usa"/> Dumbo's average office rent of $25 per square foot makes it more attractive to start-ups than Manhattan, where rents averaged $40 per square foot in 2013.<ref name="usa"/> The area has been compared to the [[Silicon Roundabout]] area in [[Shoreditch]], [[East London]], as well as to Manhattan's [[Silicon Alley]].
===Transportation=== [[New York City Subway]] stations are located at [[York Street (IND Sixth Avenue Line)|York Street]] ({{NYCS trains|Sixth far south}}) on the [[IND Sixth Avenue Line]], and [[High Street (IND Eighth Avenue Line)|High Street]] ({{NYCS trains|Cranberry}}) on the [[IND Eighth Avenue Line]].<ref>{{NYCS const|map}}</ref> [[New York City Bus]] service is provided by the {{NYC bus link|B25|B67|B69}}.<ref>{{Cite NYC bus map|B}}</ref>
Ramps and staircases connect the Brooklyn Bridge and Manhattan Bridge walkways to Dumbo.
In June 2011, [[NY Waterway]] started service to points along the East River.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/06/14/nyregion/east-river-ferry-service-begins-with-7-stops.html|title=East River Ferry Service Begins|last=Grynbaum|first=Michael M.|date=June 13, 2011|last2=Quinlan|first2=Adriane|newspaper=The New York Times|issn=0362-4331|access-date=September 23, 2016}}</ref> On May 1, 2017, that route became part of the [[NYC Ferry]]'s East River route, which runs between [[Pier 11/Wall Street]] in Manhattan's [[Financial District, Manhattan|Financial District]] and the [[East 34th Street Ferry Landing]] in [[Murray Hill, Manhattan]], with five intermediate stops in Brooklyn and Queens. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/newswires/new-york/nyc-launches-ferry-service-queens-east-river-routes-article-1.3122046|title=NYC launches ferry service with Queens, East River routes|date=May 1, 2017|website=NY Daily News|publisher=Associated Press|accessdate=May 1, 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170501154444/http://www.nydailynews.com/newswires/new-york/nyc-launches-ferry-service-queens-east-river-routes-article-1.3122046|archivedate=May 1, 2017|df=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/05/01/nyregion/new-york-today-citywide-ferry-service-begins.html|title=New York Today: Our City’s New Ferry|last=Levine|first=Alexandra S.|date=May 1, 2017|work=The New York Times|access-date=May 1, 2017|last2=Wolfe|first2=Jonathan|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> One of the East River Ferry's stops is at [[Fulton Ferry, Brooklyn|Fulton Ferry]] in Dumbo.<ref name=east-river>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ferry.nyc/routes-and-schedules/route/east-river/|title=Routes and Schedules: East River|publisher=NYC Ferry}}</ref>
